description: The JFK Coma Recovery Scale–Revised  (CRS-R)is a standardized assessment of neurobehavioral function used to assist with the differential diagnosis of various disorders of consciousness.(2,3) The CRS-R  can be used to document recovery from coma.(2,3) Additionally, the CRS-R provides a prognostic assessment and can be used to assist with treatment planning(2)
Comprises 23 items that are divided among six subscales: auditory, visual, motor, oromotor, communication, and arousal functions(2)

Subscales are arranged in a hierarchical manner, beginning with brainstem function, then subcortical processes, and finally cortical processes(2) –The first test items on each subscale are associated with reflexive functioning and the final test items represent higher-order  cognitive behaviors(2) –Higher scores reflect progressively increasing levels of neurobehavioral function
The CRS-R  is available in English, Spanish, Portuguese, Italian, German, French, Chinese, Dutch, Danish, Russian, Polish, and Norwegian(11,16,17)
Scoring is standardized and is based on whether operationally defined behavioral responses to specific sensory stimuli are present or absent in the patient being assessed(2)
The CRS-R  has good interrater reliability and internal consistency, as well as excellent test–retest  reliability (1)
indications: Individuals with disorders of consciousness; individuals in a coma(3)

The CRS-R  incorporates diagnostic guidelines based on the Aspen Workgroup criteria for coma, unresponsive wakefulness syndrome (UWS, formerly called “vegetative state” [VS]), minimally conscious state (MCS), and emergence from MCS(1)

Coma –A major complication of serious disorders of and injuries to the CNS(4) –Consciousness is depressed and the eyes remain closed; individual is stuporous and unresponsive except for possible reflexive movements with repeated vigorous sensory stimuli(4) -While in a coma, the individual is unarousable; however, he or she may exhibit some reflexive movements(4)

UWS (formerly called vegetative state) –Typically follows coma(4) –The patient shows improvement from initial comatose state; he or she typically appears awake, but remains motionless without awareness of surroundings(4)

MCS –A significantly altered state of consciousness, but improvement from unresponsive wakefulness(4) –Individuals in an MCS demonstrate inconsistent periods of consciousness with some degree of functional recovery and responsive behavior(4)

Diagnosis and early prognosis in disorders of consciousness, in particular UWS/vegetative state and MCS, is difficult, as they depend on the observation of clinical signs of responsiveness; detecting behavioral signs of awareness can be challenging –The CRS-R  is useful as patients appear to be evolving from a coma or UWS, and the diagnostic team is attempting to make an accurate differential diagnosis(12) –The CRS-R  is the most sensitive scale to differentiate the different altered states of consciousness –Eleven items detect the MCS(12)

ICD-10 codes.Additional: ICD-10 codes will vary according to the underlying cause of the coma (ICD codes are provided for the reader's reference, not for billing purposes)

CPT codes.96116:: neurobehavioral status exam (clinical assessment of thinking, reasoning and judgment, acquired knowledge, attention, language, memory, planning and problem solving, and visual spatial abilities), per hour of the psychologist’s or physician’s time, both face-to-face  time with the patient and time interpreting test results and preparing the report
CPT codes.96118:: neuropsychological testing (e.g., Halstead-Reitan Neuropsychological Battery, Wechsler Memory Scales, and Wisconsin Sorting Test), per hour of the psychologist’s or physician’s time, both face-to-face  time administering tests to the patient and interpreting these results and preparing the report
CPT codes.96119:: neuropsychological testing (e.g., Halstead-Reitan Neuropsychological Battery, Wechsler Memory Scales, and Wisconsin Sorting Test), with qualified healthcare professional interpretation and report, administered by technician, per hour of technician time, face-to-face
CPT codes.96125:: standardized cognitive performance testing (e.g., Ross Information Processing Assessment) per hour of a qualified health care professional’s time, both face-to-face  time administering tests to the patient and time interpreting these test results and preparing the report

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this assessment. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
contraindications precautions to test: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this test are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment and refer to physician orders

Vestibular stimulation is used as part of the arousal facilitation protocol in the CRS-R;  however, this is contraindicated in patients with increased intracranial pressure, acute surgical lines, or fractures and in the presence of lines and monitors(5)

Deep pressure stimulation is used as part of the arousal facilitation protocol in the CRS-R;  however, this is contraindicated over fracture sites, wounds, surgical sites, and areas around lines or monitors(5)
psychometric properties: Reliability: The CRS-R  has good interrater reliability and excellent test-retest  reliability(1)
Validity: –The CRS-R  has excellent (class I evidence) content validity and internal construct validity (1)
Internal consistency: The CRS-R  has good (class I evidence) internal consistency(1)

Sensitivity and specificity: –The ability of the CRS-R  to detect conscious awareness (i.e., MCS or emerged from minimally conscious state [EMCS]) was investigated in a retrospective study of 252 patients in the United States with disorders of consciousness(9) -A CRS-R  total score of 10 or more had a sensitivity of 0.78 for correctly identifying conscious awareness (i.e., MCS or EMCS) and a specificity of 1.00 for correctly identifying patients who did not meet conscious awareness criteria (i.e., patients in whom UWS/vegetative state or coma was diagnosed); a false-negative  diagnostic error was found in 22% of patients, who were misclassified as unconscious -Researchers concluded that a CRS-R  score cutoff of 8 provides the best optimal balance of sensitivity and specificity for detecting conscious awareness, as evidenced by a true positive rate of 93%, a true negative rate of 96%, and an accurate diagnostic classification of 93% of patients

Ceiling/floor effects: The measure was designed to assess patients at Rancho Los Amigos Levels of Cognitive Functioning I–IV ,  so it would not be appropriate for patients who are functioning beyond these levels(6)
potential complications adverse effects: Because the examiners are attempting to elicit behavioral responses from a patient with a disorder of consciousness, there is a risk that the patient could become agitated and/or combative
test preparation materials required: Supplemental forms –Brainstem Reflex Grid record form(1) –CRS-R  Total Score Progress Tracking Chart(1)
Writing utensil to record patient responses(1)
A collection of everyday objects such as a ball, cup, and spoon(1,5) –At least one object should be illuminated or brightly colored(1,5)
Tongue depressor for oral reflex assessment(5)
test procedure: The CRS-R  record forms and administration manual guide the examiner through the procedure for each portion of the test

The test begins with a 1-minute  observation of the patient in order to record baseline information about resting posture of the extremities, eye opening, visual fixing or tracking, and spontaneous movement(5)

The arousal facilitation protocol is provided in the CRS-R  to guide examiners through interventions to promote arousal from the patient and prolong the length of time the patient is able to maintain arousal(1,5) –The arousal facilitation protocol should be administered any time during the CRS-R  that the patient is -exhibiting sustained eyelid closure AND/OR(1) -not following commands for a period of at least 60 seconds(1) –The examiner is advised to re-administer  the arousal facilitation protocol when the patient is -observed with sustained eye closure OR(1) -not responding behaviorally despite sustained eye opening(1)

For each item on the test, a detailed section is provided for how to elicit behavioral responses from the patient along with the appropriate score that corresponds to each type of behavioral response.(1) The subscales are as follows: –CRS-R  Record Form(1) -Auditory Function Scale -Visual Function Scale -Authors of a multi-center,  cross-sectional study in Italy that included 52 patients with a diagnosis of MCS reported that nonreflexive visual behavior (indicating an intentional, cortically mediated response) on the CRS-R  was the most frequently detected intentional sign consistent with a diagnosis of MCS(7) -Motor Function Scale -Oromotor/Verbal Function Scale -Communication Scale -Arousal Scale –Brainstem Reflex Grid Record Form(1) -Pupillary light reflex -Corneal reflex -Spontaneous eye movement -Oculocephalic reflex -Postural responses
test scoring interpretation: For each of the six subscales of the CRS-R,  the patient is scored on his or her response to specific sensory stimuli(1) –Each subscale has a minimum score of 0; the maximum scores range from 2 to 6(1) –Items on the subscales are scored as “absent” or “present”(1) –Minimum total score is 0; maximum score is 23(1)
The CRS-R  includes tracking forms to track changes in a patient’s score over time(1)

The CRS-R  can be used to help predict patient outcome at discharge(14,15) –Researchers of a study in Italy of 110 patients with severe brain injury admitted to an intensive rehabilitation unit concluded that improvement on total CRS-R  scores and various subscales across a period of 4 weeks can help predict patient outcome at discharge(14) –Researchers of a study in Italy of 137 patients with severe brain injury found that higher CRS-R  scores taken at time of admission to an intensive rehabilitation unit correlated with improved responsiveness at patient discharge(15)

A modified CRS-R  scoring system has been proposed in an attempt to avoid overlapping scores between UWS/vegetative state and MCS, and to provide a continuum for scores from no response to more complex and reproducible behavior(8) –The modified scoring subdivides each CRS-R  response into two categories:noncognitively mediated reflex/behavior and cognitively mediated behavior

It is recommended that CRS-R  testing be performed multiple times during varied times of the day throughout the duration of care in order to minimize the risk of misclassification(10) –Based on a retrospective study in the United States including 7 patients with unresponsive wakefulness syndrome (UWS) or VS and 12 patients in the MCS state –CRS-R  scores were found to be higher in the morning than in the afternoon in the UWS/VS and MCS subgroups over the entire 13 weeks

Researchers in Belgium and the United States conducted a study to document the prevalence of items that detect MCS (i.e., signs of consciousness) in 282 patients in whom MCS was diagnosed based on the CRS-R(12) –The items that were particularly frequent were fixation, visual pursuit, and reproducible movement to command -Seen in more than 50% of the patients -These were also the items most likely to be observed when the patients showed only one sign of consciousness –Items that were rarely or never observed alone included object localization (reaching), object manipulation, intelligible verbalization, and object recognition –These results also showed that limiting the CRS-R  assessment to the five most frequently observed items (i.e., fixation, visual pursuit, reproducible movement to command, automatic motor response, and localization to noxious stimulation) detected 99% of the patients in MCS -The authors suggest that if clinicians have only limited time to assess patients with disorders of consciousness, they should evaluate at least these five items of the CRS-R

Improbable scores on the CRS-R  could relate to characteristics of the patient (e.g., deafness, blindness, aphasia, apraxia) or the examiner (novice versus expert). Researchers in the United States sought to develop a methodology that could alert the examiner to erroneous or unusual scores on the CRS-R(13) –The probability of receiving a specific score on a given subscale should be related to the scores received on the other subscales –Subscale scores that are not consistent with the hierarchical structure of the scale would have a low probability of occurring –Improbable combinations of scores on subscales suggest improper administration or scoring procedures, but could also raise red flags that further investigation is needed -For example, a high motor subscale score with a very low auditory subscale score raises the possibility of aphasia or auditory processing impairment -Conversely, a high score on auditory function, indicating consistent command following, with a 0 score on motor function (no motor response) could indicate quadriparesis or spasticity interfering with motor response –The authors identified 9 impossible and 36 improbable subscale combinations that should trigger a review of the quality of the data
